channel.title: World
channel.description: The Washington Post World section provides information and analysis of breaking world news stories. In addition to our world news and video, Post World News offers discussions and blogs on major international news and economic issues.

item.title: Israel strikes Beirut area in Lebanon for first time in days
item.dc:creator: Victoria Bisset, Amanda Coletta

item.title: Live Briefing: Israel strikes Beirut area; U.S. pushes to rekindle peace talks
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jeong, Victoria Bisset, Miriam Berger, Steve Hendrix, Amanda Coletta
item.description: U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken argued that Israel has accomplished its main objectives in Gaza and thus the “focus now must be on ending the war.”

item.title: Kim Jong Un has sent North Korean troops to Russia. What’s in it for him?
item.dc:creator: Michelle Lee
item.description: The cash-strapped North Korean leader has sent some 10,000 troops to help in Russia’s war against Ukraine. Moscow could be giving him money and nuclear know-how.

item.title: As U.S. elections loom, Ukrainian officials are ready for Trump
item.dc:creator: Isabelle Khurshudyan
item.description: Amid the sense that the status quo isn’t working, officials privately admit they are ready for a whole new approach by the U.S. administration.

item.title: More than 30 killed in Israeli attacks on central Gaza, medics say
item.dc:creator: Miriam Berger, Hazem Balousha, Alon Rom

item.title: Google fined $20 decillion — more than world’s total wealth — by Russian court
item.dc:creator: Frances Vinall
item.description: The $20,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000 fine is a response to a lawsuit by Russian channels blocked on YouTube and is largely symbolic.

item.title: As smuggling rings made billions from migrants, the U.S. was sidelined
item.dc:creator: Mary Beth Sheridan
item.description: Migrant-smuggling has become a top income stream for criminal groups in Latin America but for years the U.S. government did little to dismantle these networks.

item.title: Israel has damaged or destroyed nearly a quarter of buildings in Lebanon’s south
item.dc:creator: Meg Kelly, Imogen Piper, Evan Hill, Abbie Cheeseman

item.title: On Baalbek’s edges, the displaced watch strikes rain down on their city
item.dc:creator: Louisa Loveluck, Suzan Haidamous

item.title: The world beyond the election: The China problem
item.dc:creator: Ishaan Tharoor
item.description: No matter who wins the election, competition between the U.S. and China will continue. Still, there are major differences between Harris and Trump’s likely approaches.

item.title: IDF hits north Gaza’s last functioning hospital, officials say; U.S. envoys visit Israel
item.dc:creator: Frances Vinall, Victoria Bisset, Heba Farouk Mahfouz , Lior Soroka, Bryan Pietsch
item.description: Israel attacked Kamal Adwan Hospital, Gaza authorities said. White House officials Amos Hochstein and Brett McGurk are in Israel to meet with top leaders.

item.title: On Baalbek’s edges, the displaced watch strikes rain down on their city
item.dc:creator: Louisa Loveluck, Suzan Haidamous
item.description: Fleeing the Lebanese city of Baalbek ahead of Israeli airstrikes, thousands find shelter — but not necessarily peace of mind — in Deir al-Ahmar.

item.title: North Korea tests new ICBM as its troops appear set to join Ukraine war
item.dc:creator: Michael Birnbaum, Michelle Lee
item.description: U.S. officials condemned Pyongyang’s launch of a powerful new ballistic missile and called on China to rein in North Korea’s cooperation with Russia.

item.title: Israel has damaged or destroyed nearly a quarter of buildings in Lebanon’s south
item.dc:creator: Meg Kelly, Imogen Piper, Evan Hill, Abbie Cheeseman
item.description: Almost 6,000 structures have been affected in border villages, including at least nine religious sites demolished in controlled explosions, a Post analysis found.

item.title: U.S. diplomacy over Lebanon, Gaza sees little apparent progress
item.dc:creator: Victoria Bisset, Lior Soroka, Heba Farouk Mahfouz , Kareem Fahim, Mohamad El Chamaa, Bryan Pietsch, Hazem Balousha, John Hudson

item.title: Canada prepares for U.S. election that ‘keeps people up at night’
item.dc:creator: Amanda Coletta
item.description: Canada is dispatching top officials across the United States to stave off policies that could harm its interests if Trump returns to office.

item.title: U.K. settles novel legal case over girl’s death from air pollution
item.dc:creator: William Booth
item.description: The British government settled for an undisclosed amount with the mother of a 9-year-old girl who was the first to have “air pollution” on her death certificate.

item.title: Spain’s deadly flooding killed 159. These photos show the aftermath.
item.dc:creator: Michael Robinson Chávez
item.description: More than 150 people were killed in unprecedented floods in the Valencia region of Spain.

item.title: China built a $50 billion military stronghold in the South China Sea
item.dc:creator: Ellen Nakashima, Laris Karklis
item.description: See how China has spent tens of billions of dollars turning farm fields and seaports into military complexes on Hainan and remote outposts in the South China Sea.

item.title: Israeli attacks in Lebanon kill 6 paramedics, government says
item.dc:creator: Mohamad El Chamaa, Victoria Bisset

item.title: At Taiwan Pride, love and queer culture shine
item.dc:creator: Josh Chen, Ya Wen Li
item.description: An illustrated reflection of LGBTQ life and celebration in Taipei.

item.title: Typhoon Kong-rey makes landfall in Taiwan with high winds, heavy rain
item.dc:creator: Pei-Lin Wu, Vic Chiang, Vivian Ho, Ian Livingston
item.description: The storm, said to be the largest typhoon to hit Taiwan in 30 years, caused damage even before making landfall.

item.title: Israel attacks north Gaza hospital amid growing concern over humanitarian conditions
item.dc:creator: Victoria Bisset, Heba Farouk Mahfouz , Lior Soroka, Frances Vinall

item.title: China resists mounting pressure to do more on climate change
item.dc:creator: Christian Shepherd, Maxine Joselow
item.description: China is defying pressure to set ambitious climate targets early and to help poor nations cope with the ravages of a warming world.

item.title: Russian drones hunt civilians in streets of southern Ukrainian city
item.dc:creator: Alex Horton, Serhii Korolchuk
item.description: With Russian forces just over the river, Kherson has turned into a hunting ground for drones that appear to be focusing mainly on civilians.

item.title: What to know about UNRWA, the U.N. organization banned by Israel
item.dc:creator: Bryan Pietsch

item.title: How U.S. elections could shape Israel’s multifront Middle East war
item.dc:creator: Loveday Morris, Steve Hendrix, John Hudson

item.title: North Korea’s elite troops are in Russia to fight Ukraine: What we know
item.dc:creator: Michelle Lee
item.description: The North Korean special forces sent to Russia are the state’s best trained troops but they will face challenges with modern warfare technology, experts say.

item.title: Israel issues first citywide evacuation order in Lebanon; new head of Hezbollah delivers first address
item.dc:creator: Rachel Pannett, Victoria Bisset, Sammy Westfall
item.description: The Biden administration has asked Israel to explain what it called a “horrifying” attack on Beit Lahia, in northern Gaza, that resulted in heavy civilian losses.

item.title: Israel orders Baalbek evacuation as Hezbollah chief vows to fight
item.dc:creator: Abbie Cheeseman, Mohamad El Chamaa, Suzan Haidamous
item.description: It was the first citywide evacuation notice Israel has issued in its five-week war, forcing thousands to flee the ancient city and UNESCO world heritage site.

item.title: European countries, trailing U.S. economy, hike taxes and trim spending
item.dc:creator: William Booth, Ellen Francis, Kate Brady
item.description: The largest economies — Britain, France and Germany — are confronting sluggish growth and soaring debt as they struggle to produce their budgets for next year.

item.title: What to know about UNRWA, the U.N. organization banned by Israel
item.dc:creator: Bryan Pietsch
item.description: A pair of laws passed by the Israeli Knesset this week, however, could imperil the ability of the U.N. agency for Palestinian refugees to work in Gaza.

item.title: Israel issues first citywide evacuation order in Lebanon
item.dc:creator: Victoria Bisset, Abbie Cheeseman

item.title: U.S. inundated with claims that American arms killed Gaza civilians
item.dc:creator: Abigail Hauslohner, Michael Birnbaum
item.description: The State Department has received hundreds of reports that Israel’s use of U.S. weapons is responsible for excessive civilian casualties in Gaza.

item.title: Highest-altitude U.S. voters to cast their ballots from space
item.dc:creator: Ruby Mellen
item.description: Astronauts on the International Space Station, including two who are stuck there after a Boeing Starliner malfunctioned, said they intended to vote from orbit.

item.title: Hezbollah, seeking stability, names new leader after Nasrallah’s killing
item.dc:creator: Suzan Haidamous, Victoria Bisset, Mohamad El Chamaa, Kareem Fahim
item.description: Hezbollah said Naim Qassem — the former deputy of Hasan Nasrallah, who was assassinated by Israel last month — would helm the militant and political group.

item.title: How U.S. elections could shape Israel’s multifront Middle East war
item.dc:creator: Loveday Morris, Steve Hendrix, John Hudson
item.description: Officials and analysts say the outcome of Tuesday’s vote between Donald Trump and Kamala Harris could have major implications for Israeli actions in Iran and Gaza.

item.title: At least 95 dead, more missing in Spain’s severe floods
item.dc:creator: Chico Harlan, Anthony Faiola, Ian Livingston, Beatriz Ríos
item.description: As much as a foot of rain fell in mere hours in and around the city of Valencia, flooding homes and sweeping away cars.
